gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: GT10-11 - Fe Speciation from the U.S. GEOTRACES NAT project of the U.S. GEOTRACES program

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Profiles of concentrations of dissolved iron-binding ligands and their respective conditional stability constants Dataset Description: <p>Concentrations of dissolved iron-binding ligands and their respective conditional stability constants in water column samples from full depth stations occupied during both cruises of the U.S. GEOTRACES North Atlantic zonal transect cruises.</p><p><strong>Versions:</strong></p><p>version 5, 19 Nov. 2014: Added L3 data.<br />version 4, 14 April 2014: Revised values for KN204-1 measurements.<br />version 3, 26 June 2013: KN199-04 station 7 values corrected.<br />version 2, 10 June 2013: KN199-04 data updated, KN204-01 data added.<br />version 1, 31 Dec. 2012: Initial data submitted.</p> Acquisition Description: <p><strong>Sample collection and filtering: </strong></p><p>Water column samples were collected by the U.S. GEOTRACES sampling team from 24 modified 12 L Teflon-lined GoFlo samplers (General Oceanics) deployed on the GEOTRACES clean CTD rosette system. The U.S. GEOTRACES sampling team filtered the samples through 0.2 µm Supor Acropak filter cartridges (Pall) inside the U.S. GEOTRACES clean-air laboratory van. Near-surface samples (~2 m depth) were collected underway either on approach or leaving each station using the Ken Bruland lab towfish deployed to collect surface samples from outside the wake of the ship. Seawater from the towfish was pumped directly into the Bruland lab clean air laboratory van and filtered through 0.2 µm Supor Acropak filter cartridges. Filtered seawater samples for Fe speciation (organic complexation) analyses were collected in 500 mL acid-cleaned Nalgene narrow-mouth fluorinated high-density polyethylene bottles that were conditioned with a Milli-Q fill for at least two weeks, and rinsed three times with filtered sample, prior to sample collection. All filtered seawater samples for dissolved iron speciation from leg 1 were provided directly to the PI (Buck), who either analyzed the sample shipboard or froze the sample at -20 ºC for laboratory-based analyses post cruise.</p><p><strong>Dissolved iron speciation (organic complexation) analyses:&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Dissolved Fe speciation (organic complexation) was analyzed using a competitive ligand exchange- adsorptive cathodic stripping voltammetry (CLE-ACSV) method with salicylaldoxime as the added competing ligand (Buck et al. 2007, 2010, 2012), modified from the original Rue and Bruland (1995) method. Dissolved Fe additions of 0 to 7.5 nM were used in the titrations, for a total of at least 10 points in each titration. Deposition times of 90 to 120 s were applied to the analyses. All analyses were performed on Bioanalytical Systems (BASi) Controlled Growth Mercury Electrodes (static mercury drop setting, size 14) with Epsilon E2 (BASi) electrochemical analyzers. There are no reference samples available for iron speciation/ organic complexation measurements of iron in seawater, inhibiting a robust assessment of accuracy and precision of these analyses. This method was shown to compare well with other labs and techniques in the GEOTRACES intercalibration exercises (Buck et al. 2012).</p><p>&nbsp;</p>

gmd:credit.gmx:Anchor: Funding provided by NSF Ocean Sciences (NSF OCE) Award Number: OCE-0927453 Award URL: http://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward.do?AwardNumber=0927453

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: College of Marine Science 140 7th Ave S.

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Access Constraints: none. Use Constraints: Please follow guidelines at: http://www.bco-dmo.org/terms-use Distribution liability: Under no circumstances shall BCO-DMO be liable for any direct, incidental, special, consequential, indirect, or punitive damages that result from the use of, or the inability to use, the materials in this data submission. If you are dissatisfied with any materials in this data submission your sole and exclusive remedy is to discontinue use.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: GEOTRACES is a SCOR sponsored program; and funding for program infrastructure development is provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation.GEOTRACES gained momentum following a special symposium, S02: Biogeochemical cycling of trace elements and isotopes in the ocean and applications to constrain contemporary marine processes (GEOSECS II), at a 2003 Goldschmidt meeting convened in Japan. The GEOSECS II acronym referred to the Geochemical Ocean Section Studies To determine full water column distributions of selected trace elements and isotopes, including their concentration, chemical speciation, and physical form, along a sufficient number of sections in each ocean basin to establish the principal relationships between these distributions and with more traditional hydrographic parameters;* To evaluate the sources, sinks, and internal cycling of these species and thereby characterize more completely the physical, chemical and biological processes regulating their distributions, and the sensitivity of these processes to global change; and* To understand the processes that control the concentrations of geochemical species used for proxies of the past environment, both in the water column and in the substrates that reflect the water column.GEOTRACES will be global in scope, consisting of ocean sections complemented by regional process studies. Sections and process studies will combine fieldwork, laboratory experiments and modelling. Beyond realizing the scientific objectives identified above, a natural outcome of this work will be to build a community of marine scientists who understand the processes regulating trace element cycles sufficiently well to exploit this knowledge reliably in future interdisciplinary studies.

Stations 7 and 9 were skipped on KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'sta'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541700.rdf Name: lat_sta Units: decimal degrees Description: latitude; North is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541701.rdf Name: lon_sta Units: decimal degrees Description: longitude; East is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541702.rdf Name: depth Units: meters Description: water depth at which sample was taken; provided in original data submission. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541703.rdf Name: depth_GEOTRC_CTD Units: meters Description: Observation/sample depth in meters; calculated from CTD pressure. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541704.rdf Name: event_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES sampling events; ranges from 2001 to 2225 for KN199-04 events and from 3001 to 3282 for KN204-01 events. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541705.rdf Name: cast_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Cast identifier numbered consecutively within a station. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541706.rdf Name: lat_cast Units: decimal degrees Description: latitude where cast was made; north is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541707.rdf Name: lon_cast Units: decimal degrees Description: longitude where cast was made; east is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541708.rdf Name: date Units: yyyymmdd Description: date; UTC http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541709.rdf Name: BTL_ISO_DateTime_UTC Units: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS[.xx][+/-TZ] Description: Date and time (UTC) variable recorded at the bottle sampling time in ISO compliant format. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). This standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on the following form: 2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time) http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541710.rdf Name: sample_GEOTRC Units: integer Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES samples; ranges from 5033 to 6078 for KN199-04 and from 6112 to 8148 for KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'sample; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541711.rdf Name: sample_bottle_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Unique identification numbers given to samples taken from bottles; ranges from 1 to 24; often used synonymously with bottle number. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541712.rdf Name: bottle_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Alphanumeric characters identifying bottle type (e.g. NIS representing Niskin and GF representing GOFLO) and position on a CTD rosette. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541713.rdf Name: flag Units: integer Description: quality flag:1 = sample not analyzed; these are noted also as "nd" = "no data"2 = sample analyzed shipboard (not frozen)3 = sample analyzed frozen (-20 degreesC)4 = sample analyzed both shipboard and after freezing http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541714.rdf Name: num_titrations Units: integer Description: number of titrations performed for sample analyses. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541715.rdf Name: Fe_ligand_1 Units: nanomoles/liter Description: average concentration of dissolved iron-binding ligand with log K1 > 12; determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541716.rdf Name: L1_std_dev Units: nanomoles/liter Description: standard deviation of average L1 concentration only provided for samples with n titrations > 1 http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541717.rdf Name: log_K1 Units: dimensionless Description: log of conditional stability constant (K^cond(FeL1;Fe')) of L1 dissolved iron-binding ligand determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations; no units but K1 has units of M-1 http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541718.rdf Name: log_K1_std_dev Units: dimensionless Description: standard deviation of average log K1; no units; K1 has units of M-1, only provided for samples with n titrations > 1 http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541719.rdf Name: Fe_ligand_2 Units: nanomoles/liter Description: concentration of dissolved iron-binding ligand with log K2 = 11-12; determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations; in nM. 'nd' = 'not detected'. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541720.rdf Name: L2_std_dev Units: nanomoles/liter Description: standard deviation of average L2 concentration; in nM; only provided for samples with n titrations > 1. 'no_det' = 'not detected'. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541721.rdf Name: log_K2 Units: dimensionless Description: log of conditional stability constant (K^cond_(FeL2;Fe')) of L2 dissolved iron-binding ligand determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations; no units; but K2 has units of M-1. 'no_det' = 'not detected'. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541722.rdf Name: log_K2_std_dev Units: dimensionless Description: standard deviation of average log K2; no units; K2 has units of M-1; only provided for samples with n titrations > 1. 'no_det' = 'not detected'. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541723.rdf Name: L3_std_dev Units: nanoMoles Description: standard deviation of average L3 concentration; only provided for samples with n titrations > 1 http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541724.rdf Name: log_K3 Units: dimensionless Description: log of conditional stability constant of L3 dissolved iron-binding ligand determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations; no units but K3 has units of M-1 http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541725.rdf Name: log_K3_std_dev Units: dimensionless Description: standard deviation of average log K3; K3 has units of M-1; only provided for samples with n titrations > 1 http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/541726.rdf Name: Fe_ligand_3 Units: nanoMoles Description: concentration of dissolved iron-binding ligand with log K3 = 10-11; determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations; in nM. 'no_det' = 'not detected'.

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Official cruise identifier e.g. KN199-04 = R/V Knorr cruise number 199-04.; General Description: cruise designation; name

PI-supplied Description: local cruise name; General Description: The cruise_name is a local name chosen by project investigators for a research expedition on a vessel, as opposed to the formal/official cruise ID asserted by the vessel operator.

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES station number; ranges from 1 through 12 for KN199-04 and 1 through 24 for KN204-01. Stations 7 and 9 were skipped on KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'sta'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: station number; generally sequential; a unique number designating a general geographic location at which one or more sampling activities may occur.* Please use station rather than sta

PI-supplied Description: latitude; North is positive; General Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South; Reported in some datasets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: longitude; East is positive; General Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West; Reported in some datsets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: water depth at which sample was taken; provided in original data submission.; General Description: observation/sample depth, in meters; best estimate; usually but not always calculated from pressure; calculated either from CTD pressure using Fofonoff and Millard (1982; UNESCO Tech Paper #44) algorithm adjusted for 1980 equation of state for seawater (EOS80) or simply equivalent to nominal depth as recorded during sampling if CTD pressure was unavailable NERC Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface.

PI-supplied Description: Observation/sample depth in meters; calculated from CTD pressure. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: observation/sample depth, in meters; best estimate; usually but not always calculated from pressure; calculated either from CTD pressure using Fofonoff and Millard (1982; UNESCO Tech Paper #44) algorithm adjusted for 1980 equation of state for seawater (EOS80) or simply equivalent to nominal depth as recorded during sampling if CTD pressure was unavailable NERC Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface.

PI-supplied Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES sampling events; ranges from 2001 to 2225 for KN199-04 events and from 3001 to 3282 for KN204-01 events. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: event or operation number; often derived from date/time (MMDDHHmm) of sampling and when combined with year (YYYY) is a unique sampling identifier/data processing key. Date/time is not necessarily in GMT.

PI-supplied Description: Cast identifier numbered consecutively within a station. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: cast or profile number

PI-supplied Description: latitude where cast was made; north is positive; General Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South; Reported in some datasets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: longitude where cast was made; east is positive; General Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West; Reported in some datsets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: date; UTC; General Description: date; generally reported in GMT as YYYYMMDD (year; month; day); also as MMDD (month; day); EqPac dates are local Hawaii time NERC Description: Unavailable

gco:attributeType.xlink:title: Date and time (UT in ISO8601 format to sub-second precision)

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Date and time (UTC) variable recorded at the bottle sampling time in ISO compliant format. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). This standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on the following form: 2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time); General Description: Date/Time (UTC) ISO formattedThis standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on any of the following forms:2009-08-30T09:05:00[.xx] (local time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]-05:00The dashes and the colons can be dropped.The T can also be dropped "by mutual agreement", but one needs the trailing Z if the time is UTC.Sample ISO_datetime_utc:2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)Format: YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS[.xx]Z (UTC time) NERC Description: String corresponding to format 'yyyy-mm-ddThh:mi:ss.sss' optionally terminated by 'Z'

PI-supplied Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES samples; ranges from 5033 to 6078 for KN199-04 and from 6112 to 8148 for KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'sample; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: unique sample identification or number; any combination of alpha numeric characters; precise definition is file dependent NERC Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers

PI-supplied Description: Unique identification numbers given to samples taken from bottles; ranges from 1 to 24; often used synonymously with bottle number. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: Niskin sample bottle number

PI-supplied Description: Alphanumeric characters identifying bottle type (e.g. NIS representing Niskin and GF representing GOFLO) and position on a CTD rosette. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: water bottle number, generally assigned to a position on a CTD rosette, identifies all samples drawn from a given bottle

PI-supplied Description: quality flag:1 = sample not analyzed; these are noted also as "nd" = "no data"2 = sample analyzed shipboard (not frozen)3 = sample analyzed frozen (-20 degreesC)4 = sample analyzed both shipboard and after freezing; General Description: Data flag. Multiple uses which are dataset dependent. Some uses: data quality, collection occurance or success, depth indicator. See dataset documentation for specific details
PI-supplied Description: number of titrations performed for sample analyses.; General Description: association with a community-wide standard parameter is not yet defined

PI-supplied Description: average concentration of dissolved iron-binding ligand with log K1 > 12; determined from both linearizations of each titration combined over replicate titrations; General Description: Concentration of a trace metal in seawater. Refer to dataset for element name and units. NERC Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material.

'nd' = 'not detected'.; General Description: Concentration of a trace metal in seawater. Refer to dataset for element name and units. NERC Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material.

PI-supplied Description: standard deviation of average L2 concentration; in nM; only provided for samples with n titrations > 1. 'no_det' = 'not detected'.; General Description: Generic standard deviation value, taking on the units of the parameter that it is tied to.

'no_det' = 'not detected'.; General Description: association with a community-wide standard parameter is not yet defined

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: <p><strong>Sample collection and filtering: </strong></p><p>Water column samples were collected by the U.S. GEOTRACES sampling team from 24 modified 12 L Teflon-lined GoFlo samplers (General Oceanics) deployed on the GEOTRACES clean CTD rosette system. The U.S. GEOTRACES sampling team filtered the samples through 0.2 µm Supor Acropak filter cartridges (Pall) inside the U.S. GEOTRACES clean-air laboratory van. Near-surface samples (~2 m depth) were collected underway either on approach or leaving each station using the Ken Bruland lab towfish deployed to collect surface samples from outside the wake of the ship. Seawater from the towfish was pumped directly into the Bruland lab clean air laboratory van and filtered through 0.2 µm Supor Acropak filter cartridges. Filtered seawater samples for Fe speciation (organic complexation) analyses were collected in 500 mL acid-cleaned Nalgene narrow-mouth fluorinated high-density polyethylene bottles that were conditioned with a Milli-Q fill for at least two weeks, and rinsed three times with filtered sample, prior to sample collection. All filtered seawater samples for dissolved iron speciation from leg 1 were provided directly to the PI (Buck), who either analyzed the sample shipboard or froze the sample at -20 ºC for laboratory-based analyses post cruise.</p><p><strong>Dissolved iron speciation (organic complexation) analyses:&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Dissolved Fe speciation (organic complexation) was analyzed using a competitive ligand exchange- adsorptive cathodic stripping voltammetry (CLE-ACSV) method with salicylaldoxime as the added competing ligand (Buck et al. 2007, 2010, 2012), modified from the original Rue and Bruland (1995) method. Dissolved Fe additions of 0 to 7.5 nM were used in the titrations, for a total of at least 10 points in each titration. Deposition times of 90 to 120 s were applied to the analyses. All analyses were performed on Bioanalytical Systems (BASi) Controlled Growth Mercury Electrodes (static mercury drop setting, size 14) with Epsilon E2 (BASi) electrochemical analyzers. There are no reference samples available for iron speciation/ organic complexation measurements of iron in seawater, inhibiting a robust assessment of accuracy and precision of these analyses. This method was shown to compare well with other labs and techniques in the GEOTRACES intercalibration exercises (Buck et al. 2012).</p><p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Data processing:</strong></p><p>Dissolved Fe concentrations for each sample from the Peter Sedwick lab at Old Dominion University were used to calculate ligand concentrations and conditional stability constants from the titrations. Titration data was interpreted with a combination of Scatchard (Scatchard 1949) and van den Berg-Ruzic (Ruzic 1982; van den Berg 1982) linearization techniques, as has been described previously (Buck et al. 2007, 2010, 2012). An inorganic side reaction coefficient, a<sub>Fe</sub><sub>¢</sub>, of 10<sup>10</sup> was used in the Fe speciation calculations (Buck et al. 2012). Ligand concentrations and conditional stability constants determined from each linearization of a titration dataset were then combined to get an average ligand concentration and conditional stability constant for each sample. Results from replicate analyses were averaged together and the average with standard deviations of all sample titrations are then reported for each parameter in the spreadsheet.</p><p>The detection limit for the electroactive Fe-SA complex has been found to be 0.01 nM (Buck et al. 2007), calculated as three times the standard deviation of peak height from a 0.05 nM Fe addition to UV-oxidized and chelexed seawater over a 900 s deposition time. For the 90 s deposition times employed for this dataset, the detection limit for Fe-SA is ~0.1 nM. Two stations from the US GTNA cruises (2010-Stn5 and 2010-Stn 9) were analyzed in triplicate complete titrations, two conducted shipboard and one (or more) in the laboratory after storing frozen (-20 ºC). The average standard deviation from the triplicate titrations of each sample was 0.11 nM over the full water column of results from both stations (n = 36 samples, 108 titrations). For log K<sub>1</sub> values of this ligand class, from the same profiles, the average standard deviation was 0.15 (log units). If the detection limit for ligand concentration was three times the average standard deviation of results from replicate titrations, then the detection limit would be 0.33 nM for L<sub>1</sub> concentrations in this dataset.</p><p><strong>Related files and references:&nbsp; </strong></p><p>Buck, K. N., M. C. Lohan, C. J. M. Berger, and K. W. Bruland. 2007. Dissolved iron speciation in two distinct river plumes and an estuary: Implications for riverine iron supply. Limnology and Oceanography <strong>52: </strong>843-855.</p><p>Buck, K. N., K. E. Selph, and K. A. Barbeau. 2010. Iron-binding ligand production and copper speciation in an incubation experiment of Antarctic Peninsula shelf waters from the Bransfield Strait, Southern Ocean. Marine Chemistry <strong>122: </strong>148-159.</p><p>Buck, K. N., J. W. Moffett, K. A. Barbeau, R. M. Bundy, Y. Kondo, and J. Wu. 2012. The organic complexation of iron and copper: an intercomparison of competitive ligand exchange- adsorptive cathodic stripping voltammetry (CLE-ACSV) techniques. Limnology and Oceanography: Methods <strong>10: </strong>496-515.</p><p>Rue, E. L., and K. W. Bruland. 1995. Complexation of iron(III) by natural organic ligands in the Central North Pacific as determined by a new competitive ligand equilibration adsorptive cathodic stripping voltammetric method. Marine Chemistry <strong>50: </strong>117-138.</p><p>Buck, K. N., B. Sohst, and P. N. Sedwick. in press, 2014. The organic complexation of dissolved iron along the U.S. GEOTRACES (GA03) North Atlantic Section. Deep-Sea Research. doi: 10.1016/j.dsr2.2014.11.016.</p><p>Ružić, I. 1982. Theoretical aspects of the direct titration of natural waters and its information yield for trace metal speciation. Analytica Chimica Acta <strong>140: </strong>99-113.</p><p>Scatchard, G. 1949. The attractions of proteins for small molecules and ions. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences <strong>51: </strong>660-672.</p><p>van den Berg, C. M. G. 1982. Determination of copper complexation with natural organic ligands in sea water by equilibrium with MnO<sub>2</sub>: I. Theory. Marine Chemistry <strong>11: </strong>307-322.</p><p><strong>BCO-DMO Processing:</strong><br />- added conventional header with dataset name, PI name, version date<br />- renamed parameters to BCO-DMO standard<br />- added lat_sta, lon_sta to enable mapping of entire profile<br />- changed lon_cast to negative values<br />- replaced blank cells and 'nda' with nd, no data available; changed nd to no_det, not detected<br />- replaced spaces with underscores<br />- joined submitted data with master event data (columns starting with GEOTRC_)</p>

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: GO-FLO Teflon Trace Metal PI Supplied Instrument Description:24 modified 12 L Teflon-lined GoFlo samplers (General Oceanics) Instrument Name: GO-FLO Teflon Trace Metal Bottle Instrument Short Name:GO-FLO Teflon TM Instrument Description: GO-FLO Teflon-lined Trace Metal free sampling bottles are used for collecting water samples for trace metal, nutrient and pigment analysis. The GO-FLO sampling bottle is designed specifically to avoid sample contamination at the surface, internal spring contamination, loss of sample on deck (internal seals), and exchange of water from different depths. Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/30/

PI Supplied Instrument Name: GeoFish Instrument Name: GeoFish Towed near-Surface Sampler Instrument Short Name:GeoFish Instrument Description: The GeoFish towed sampler is a custom designed near surface (<2m) sampling system for the collection of trace metal clean seawater. It consists of a PVC encapsulated lead weighted torpedo and separate PVC depressor vane supporting the intake utilizing all PFA Teflon tubing connected to a deck mounted, air-driven, PFA Teflon dual-diaphragm pump which provides trace-metal clean seawater at up to 3.7L/min. The GeoFish is towed at up to 13kts off to the side of the vessel outside of the ship's wake to avoid possible contamination from the ship's hull. It was developed by Geoffrey Smith and Ken Bruland (University of California, Santa Cruz). Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/31/

PI Supplied Instrument Name: Autoanalyzer BASi EC-epsilon 2 PI Supplied Instrument Description:All analyses were performed on Bioanalytical Systems (BASi) Controlled Growth Mercury Electrodes (static mercury drop setting, size 14) with Epsilon 2 (BASi) electrochemical analyzers. Instrument Name: BASi EC-epsilon 2 Autoanalyzer Instrument Short Name:BASi EC-epsilon 2 Instrument Description: The Bioanalytical Systems EC epsilon is a family of potentiostat/galvanostats for electrochemistry. The most basic epsilon instrument can be used for standard techniques, as well as chronopotentiometry for materials characterization (e.g., characterization of transition metal complexes by cyclic voltammetry and controlled potential electrolysis, or of biosensors by cyclic voltammetry and constant potential amperometry). Pulse, square wave, and stripping techniques can be added by a software upgrade, and a second channel can be added by a hardware upgrade.http://www.basinc.com/products/ec/epsilon/

PI Supplied Instrument Name: BASi Controlled Growth Mercury Electrode PI Supplied Instrument Description:Controlled Growth Mercury Electrodes on Static Mercury Drop Electrode (SMDE) setting, size 14. Instrument Name: BASi Controlled Growth Mercury Electrode Instrument Short Name:BASI CGME Instrument Description: Bioanalytical Systems (BASi) Mercury drop electrodes are generated by the BASi Controlled Growth Mercury Electrode (CGME) in three modes: DME (Dropping Mercury Electrode) - mercury is allowed to flow freely from the reservoir down the capillary and so the growth of the mercury drop and its lifetime is controlled by gravity. (The optional 100 um capillary is recommended for this mode.) SMDE (Static Mercury Drop Electrode) - the drop size is determined by the length of time for which the fast-response capillary valve is opened, and the drop is dislodged by a drop knocker. The dispense/knock timing is microprocessor-controlled and is typically coordinated with the potential pulse or square-wave waveform. This mode can also used to generate the Hanging Mercury Drop Electrode required for stripping experiments. CGME (Controlled Growth Mercury Electrode) - the mercury drop is grown by a series of pulses that open the capillary valve. The number of pulses, their duration, and their frequency can be varied by PC control, providing great flexibility in both the drop size and its rate of growth. This CGME mode can be used for both polarographic and stripping experiments.http://www.basinc.com/products/ec/cgme.php
